cluster_relations.rel_desc: Predators of butterfly eggs prey on butterflies in the egg stage.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: near or on leaves where eggs are laid
qualifiers.CausalHint: threat that motivates protective egg-laying behavior

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillars in the larval stage feed on plant leaves as their primary food source.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Butterfly Egg-Laying Sites and Larval Food Leaves
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: most of their time spent feeding
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Behavior: voracious eating and rapid growth while feeding

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Predators of caterpillars prey upon caterpillars.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when caterpillars are detected despite camouflage/defenses

remarks: Predation is implied rather than explicitly spelled out.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject organism (predator) preys upon, harms, or consumes the object organism or life stage as a food source.
args.justification: Both relations describe predators consuming butterfly eggs or caterpillars, i.e., a clear predation relationship where the subject is a predator and the object is the preyed-upon life stage.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject organism consumes the object as a primary or regular food source, without necessarily implying a predator-prey dynamic.
args.justification: This relation describes caterpillars consuming plant leaves as food, which is a feeding (herbivory) interaction rather than predation on another animal; using a distinct predicate 'feeds_on' better captures this consumer-resource relation.

All three relations involve energy/food transfer between organisms or between an organism and its food resource (predation on eggs and caterpillars, and caterpillars feeding on leaves), which are classic trophic interactions.
Trophic and feeding relationships are ecological interactions between entities, best captured under a broad interaction-oriented group rather than composition, identity, or causality.

All three relations involve energy/food transfer between organisms or between an organism and its food resource (predation on eggs and caterpillars, and caterpillars feeding on leaves), which are classic trophic interactions.
